passages.text: Longing for a turnaround

For investors who want to play a medium- term turnaround story among non- SOE Chinese developers, we believe Longfor remains the best candidate with favourable risk- reward, because: 1) default risk is low with a comfortable balance sheet; 2) recurring net income of Rmb8- 9bn provides a solid buffer; 3) management remains one of the more capital- market- friendly ones (peers such as Vanke & Seazen no longer host result briefings, while Longfor not only hosts a results call, but also remains active in roadshows & conferences). Tactically, if there is significant policy easing in the housing market, we believe Longfor may offer \(>70\%\) upside if we simply benchmark to the peak in October 2024. However, even if we assume 'no big policy', we believe Longfor may still retare gradually to \(\sim \mathrm{HK}\) 14 (33% potential upside) in the medium term, if we apply a 10x P/E to recurring (non- DP) net income (assuming zero value from DP). From a trading perspective, we also observe Longfor seems to have found a solid support level at \(>HK\) 9.

A transformation in the making: Longfor's earlier strategy of actively building recurring income is paying off amid the current industry backdrop, as Longfor has been able to raise commercial property loans & long- term rental loans (latest balance: Rmb93bn), which have much longer tenure ( \(>10\) years) and lower financing costs ( \(3 - 4\%\) ) to repay bonds. We estimate Longfor still has capacity to raise another Rmb10- 15bn, which can cover the outstanding balance of offshore bonds (Rmb9.5bn). Meanwhile, the Rmb8.0- 8.5bn FY25E net profit from recurring income (likely Rmb10bn in a few years' time) helps offset the earnings dilution from DP. Over the next few years, we expect Longfor to transform from a DP- focused developer into a recurring income- focused asset manager (Figure 6).

Admittedly, the drag from DP is not behind us: Longfor's 1H25 core net profit dropped \(71\%\) Y/Y (more in our First Take) due to gross development property (DP) margin dropping to only \(0.2\%\) (implying a net loss). From an earnings perspective, we think the worst is not over. We forecast FY25E core net profit to drop \(80\%\) Y/Y to Rmb1.4bn (implying almost no profit in 2H25E) (Figure 1), as the low- margin DP projects ( \(0 - 1\%\) gross margin) will still drag down overall earnings (we forecast recurring net profit to be Rmb8.0- 8.5bn in FY25E, implying a net loss of Rmb6.6- 7.1bn from DP). However, we expect earnings to rebound in FY26E and FY27E, and although the low- margin projects may remain dilutive (Figure 2), we believe the impact on overall earnings should start to ease.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

- OCF will likely remain positive: Encouragingly, we saw further improvement in Longfor's balance sheet in 1H25 (net gearing stable at 51%; cash coverage on short-term debt improving from 1.0x to 1.1x; average financing cost down from 4.0% to 3.6%; average debt maturity up from 10 years to 11 years – Figure 5). In 1H25, Longfor reported positive OCF (including capex) of Rmb2bn+, and we forecast Longfor will achieve positive OCF of ~Rmb10bn in FY25E (Table 1) as long as Longfor remains inactive in land-banking. In our stress test, to ensure OCF does not turn negative, Longfor's monthly contracted sales in 2H25E need to be >Rmb5bn (or higher than a 39% Y/Y decline), which we believe is manageable. That said, if sales momentum turns out to be much worse than expected, we cannot rule out the possibility of share placement (after all, Longfor is one of the few non-distressed POE developers which have not raised funds through share placement since the liquidity crisis began in 2021).

Key Metrics (FYE Dec)

Among key non- SOE Chinese developers, we believe by now Longfor has almost been confirmed to be 'the last man standing' amid the industry turmoil. Despite the likely continual weakness in DP earnings, we look beyond this and focus on Longfor's expanding recurring income. In the medium term, we believe Longfor is set to be a solid turnaround story as it transforms into an asset manager.
Our Jun- 26 price target of HK\$14.0 is based on a 0.55x target P/B, which implies a target forward P/E of 10x for recurring income only (assuming no value from DP).

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid- cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
